awd_titl_txt: Late Quaternary Variability of the Agulhas Thermohaline Valve from Nd Isotopes in Planktonic Foraminifera
awd_abstract_narration: As a component of the shallow warm water return route of the "great ocean conveyor", and as the largest western boundary current in the world ocean, the Agulhas Current plans an important role in the transfer of heat and salt into the Atlantic Ocean. This "leakage" of Indian Ocean waters into the South Atlantic contributes to increased salinification of the thermocline. This preconditioning effect provides a positive feedback for North Atlantic Deep Water (NADW) formation, and thereby may play a critical role in driving the Meridional Overturning Circulation. This research investigates changes in the "Agulhas Leakage" (AL) over the last 30,000 years, seeking to better constrain the role that the oceanic water exchange via leakage had in past climate changes as an active player in major circulatory changes in the Atlantic. The neodymium isotopic composition of planktonic foraminifera will be used to reconstruct changes in the Agulhas Leakage intensity and position. The research centers around four hypotheses: 1) the AL is greater during warmer climate periods (and vice versa), 2) increases in AL contributed to increases in NADW export during the deglaciation, 3) decreases in AL contributed to decreased NADW export during the climate transition of the last glacial period, and 4) the position of the Agulhas retroflection was the same during the Holocene and LGM. Funding supports a postdoctoral researcher and application of a new paleoceanographic proxy.

por.por_cntn:
In the context of rapid increases in atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations as a result of anthropogenic emissions, there is an urgent need to understand how the climate system (e.g. oceanic and atmospheric circulation) could respond to such perturbations. In this sense, the Southern Ocean plays a pivotal role in the global ocean thermohaline circulation (Image 1) which essentially transports intermediate and deep waters in a 'conveyor belt' fashion around the planet. Both intermediate and deep-ocean waters redistribute heat, salt and chemical species such as dissolved CO2, therefore constituting an important mechanism controlling global climate on short and long time-scales.

In this project, we have reconstructed the past strength of earth’s system of deep-ocean currents by sampling deep-sea sediments off the coast of South Africa, where powerful currents originating in the North Atlantic Ocean pass on their way to Antarctica. How vigorously those currents moved in the past can be inferred by how much North Atlantic water made it that far, as measured by isotope ratios of the element neodymium bearing the signature of North Atlantic seawater. Like a tape recorder, the shells of ancient plankton (Image 2) incorporate this seawater signal through time, allowing scientists to approximate when the currents grew stronger and weaker off South Africa.

For the duration of this award we have separated the intermediate and deep-ocean components in two different subproject, but with a clear linkage between both of them.

Our initial interest was devoted to how intermediate water masses, such as Antarctic Intermediate Water (AAIW) responded to rapid climate perturbations during the last 30,000 years. This is relevant as these water masses are regarded as the single most important pathway for the uptake of anthropogenic CO2 from the Atmosphere and for transporting it to the ocean interior (Image 3). Thus, a deeper understanding of how intermediate waters were perturbated during past rapid climate events will provide insights on potential future perturbations due to global warming. By measuring isotope ratios of the element neodymium bearing the signature of Antarctic Intermediate Waters we were able to reconstruct a significant increase in the volume export and transport of these waters during cold periods such as the Last Glacial Maximum 20,000 years ago. This behaviour is repeated everytime that the planet goes under a rapid cold spell, thus indication a strong correlation between climate and ocean dynamics.

Our second interest was focused on one of the climate puzzles from the recent geological past, the so-called mid-Pleistocene Transition. For decades, climate scientists have tried to explain why ice-age cycles became longer and more intense about 900,000 years ago, switching from  1,000-year cycles to 100,000-year cycles. In this project we have found that the deep ocean currents that move heat around the globe stalled or even stopped, possibly due to expanding ice cover in the north. The slowing currents increased carbon dioxide storage in the ocean, leaving less in the atmosphere, which kept temperatures cold and kicked the climate system into a new phase of colder but less frequent ice ages.

Using sediments from two core sites in the South Atlantic and measuring Neodymium isotope ratios on fossil shells we have estimated that over the last 1.2 million years the conveyor-like currents strengthened during warm periods and weakened during ice ages, as previously known, but at about 900,000 years ago, the ocean circulation weakened significantly and stayed weak for about 100,000 years before the system recovered and entered a new phase of longer 100,000 year ice age cycles.
